Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 20, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
*Note – no citations were related to restrictions as a result of COVID-19
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
AGENCY SERVICES
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
Three references were not obtained before employment for one
of seven new employees.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
A central registry clearance was not obtained before
employment for one of seven new employees. The case aid
was hired on 2/17/19 and his clearance was obtained on 5/4/20.
4

FOSTER HOME CERTIFICATION
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(a) All changes to the factual information contained in the
initial evaluation and subsequent renewal evaluations.
A change in the foster parent’s employment status was not
documented in the annual inspection report for one of four
foster homes.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
A licensing recommendation was not made to the department at
least 15 days before the expiration of the foster home license for
one of four foster homes.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
When additional time beyond 45 days was required, the agency
did not inform the foster parent in writing of the basis and
expected length of the extension for one of four special
evaluations.
5

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
Conclusions regarding compliance was not based on the
findings for two of four special evaluations (SE). In one SE,
the foster parent interview did not match the licensing rule being
investigated. A second SE did not thoroughly interview the
substitute caregiver to determine whether or not the agency’s
supervision policy was followed as presented to her by the
licensed foster parent.
(Repeat violation in 2018)
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) – (i)
Four of six initial placement outlines were either not completed
or were completed more than 7 days after placement. The
completed documents were not uploaded into MISACWIS.
(Repeat violation in 2019)
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a - j)
6

One of two DHHS-69’s was completed two months after the
change of placement occurred.
(Repeat violation in 2019)
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
(b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical, and dental
care.
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
Three of six required new physical examinations were either
not completed or were completed late. The two exams that
were not completed were overdue on 6/17/19 and 3/2/20.
(Repeat violations in 2018 & 2019)
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of six children requiring a new dental examination was
completed four months late. .
7

R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a - j)
One of six foster parent information documentation was
noncompliant. It could not be determined when the document
was completed or if it was provided to the foster parent because
it was not signed or dated by the worker or the foster parent.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a) Two of four Initial Service Plans (ISPs) were completed
70 and 108 days late.
(b)Nine of eighteen Updated Service Plans (USPs) for six
children were completed 15, 49, 52, 59, 96, 104, 148,
187 and 238 days late.
((b) Repeat violation in 2018 & 2019)
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
8

(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
Two of six foster children had one missed home visit each in
August and September 2019.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
In two of two closed foster child records, the DHHS-69’s were
completed four and five months after the change of placement
occurred.
INDEPENDENT LIVING SERVICES
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(a) All of the following personal information pertaining to the
youth:
(i) Name.
(ii) Social security number.
(iii) Address and telephone number.
(iv) Date of birth.
(v) Gender
(vi) Race.
(vii) Height.
(viii) Weight.
(ix) Hair color.
(x) Eye color.
(xi) Identifying marks.
9

In two of two IL youth records, personal information pertaining
to the youth was not updated at least once every 90 days.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420.
Three of eight service plans were completed late for one of two
IL youth. The plans were 2, 8 and 21 days late.
(Repeat violation in 2019)
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
An updated contract due August 2019 was not completed for
one of two IL youth.
(Repeat violation in 2018)
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Note there are additional
ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance
will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
10

ISEP 6.49 Quarterly medical passports
One of six children were missing two quarterly medical
passports.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Note there are
additional DDHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DDHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Quarterly Family Team Meetings (FTM’s)
Four FTM’s were missed on two of six foster children.
(Repeat violation in 2018)
ADM 400 MARE within 30 days of case acceptance
Five of six children available for adoption were not registered
on MARE or were registered in excess of 30 days after case
acceptance. Three are past due and not registered. Three
were registered 8, 10 and 10 months after case acceptance.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report timeliness
Seven of seven quarterly progress reports for four children
were completed 1, 3, 5, 6, 8, 8, and 8 months late. All quarterly
reports were completed after this Renewal inspection
commenced.
ADM 400 Adoptive Child Assessment (form 1927) within 45 days
Six of six Adoptive Child Assessments were noncompliant.
Three are past due now. Three were completed 8, 10 and 10
months late. All completed assessments were done after this
Renewal inspection commenced.
11

FOM 722.05 Case documentation – All case documents must be
maintained in the child’s electronic record in MISACWIS.
Significant case documentation that was completed was not
uploaded into MISACWIS (ie, initial placement outlines, Child
Adoption Assessments, Adoption Progress reports and
Independent Living contracts and budgets).
IV. CONSULTATION
Although sibling visits can now occur during parenting time, they must be identified
in MISACWIS as sibling visits in order to be accurately counted and tracked.
When a child is placed in a Guiding Harbor foster home by another agency,
it is recommended that Guiding Harbor complete a body chart on the child at the
time of placement. The body chart should be signed, dated and time-stamped by
the worker completing it.
It is recommended that only those social work contacts relevant to the specific
renewal, annual or special evaluation be linked to the report in MISACWIS.
It is recommended that the source of the allegation not be identified in the special
evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation (1) (d) indicates workers with children in
the home are to be notified that an investigation was initiated and (6) (c) and
provided a copy of the special evaluation report. It is recommended the worker(s)
be interviewed if he/she has information that may contribute to the findings of fact.
V. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse, neglect or corporal
punishment during this licensing period.
The agency had no DCWL investigations during this licensing period.
The agency submitted one corrective action plan for the 2019 Interim Inspection
during this licensing period with the following violations:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation (2) (d)
R 400.12404 Placement (7) (a – i)
R 400. 12405 Change of placement (3) (a – j)
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy (1) (c) (ii)
R 400.12418 Development of service plans (2) (b) & (3)
12

R 400.12509 Independent living record (3) (o)
R 400.12511 Independent living termination (1) (a – d)
ISEP 6.18 Relative Foster Parent Licensing Timeliness
FOM 722.08C Caregiver signatures on PATPs
FOM 722-6H Quarterly unannounced visits
VI. ANALYST FINDINGS
The analyst identified no safety concerns in the homes visited.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, ISEP requirements and/or DHHS contract/policies. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
